awd_titl_txt: RCN:  SedHeat - Building an Interdisciplinary Community to Meet the Science, Engineering, and Educational Challenges for Sustainable Geothermal Energy from Sedimentary Basins
awd_abstract_narration:
RCN: SedHeat - Building an Interdisciplinary Community to Meet the Science, Engineering, and Educational Challenges for Sustainable Geothermal Energy from Sedimentary Basins

John Holbrook, Texas Christian University, EAR-1240138

ABSTRACT
This proposal will support a Research Coordination Network that will draw together an interdisciplinary group of geoscientists, engineers, educators, and economists dedicated 'to form a central point of unity, exchange, and education to exceed the science and engineering challenges of sedimentary-basin geothermal energy' as its central stated goal. The RCN builds off the NSF SEES Workshop -Tracking an energy elephant: science and engineering challenges for unlocking the geothermal potential of sedimentary basins,- which was held November 2011 in Salt Lake City. This workshop included 71 participants, and was convened to address the question "What are the basic science and engineering questions that need to be addressed in order to make geothermal energy production from sedimentary basins practical?" The November 2011 SEES Workshop concluded that geothermal energy from sedimentary basins has the realistic potential to supply energy on the gigawatt scales of coal and nuclear. The barriers to sedimentary-basin geothermal are within the risk and uncertainty of economic extraction. Addition of sedimentary-basin geothermal to the U.S. energy portfolio would have a tremendous impact on the sustainability of the energy grid and the economy at large with negligible environmental impact.  The program will strive to develop an educated community though preparation of course materials and directly reaching out to students though short courses and student lab visitation opportunities.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the SedHeat Research Coordination Network is "to form a central point of unity, exchange, and education to exceed the science and engineering challenges of sedimentary-basin geothermal energy."  Following this goal, over 300 members have developed an interdisciplinary community from industry, academia, and government to define and overcome the challenges in tapping the geothermal energy supply.  We did this by organizing larger meetings and smaller working groups where we discuss ideas, and then dividing into a series of smaller coordinated groups that researched critical topics.

Geothermal energy remains the sleeping giant of clean energy.  The geothermal energy stored beneath the United States is several thousand times the energy we use in total for a year, meaning a virturally indefinate energy supply.  Our challenge is and remains how to economically access this vast storehouse of energy.  SedHeat focuses on that part of the total geothermal energy stored in sedimentary basins.  The United States is blessed with many deep sedimentary basins, and these basins collectively hold a 1000 years of energy reserves at the current total U.S. consumption rate.  Sedimentary basins have sufficient porosity to permit water to be pumped from injection to extraction wells as a way to extract heat.  We set out to find a way to make this process a reality.  The potential economic impact and job creation from building a new and affordable energy source with a lower overall environmental impact is the broader impact SedHeat sets out to bring to society.

SedHeat has led to tangible advancements.  Our group has researched the distribution and quanity of the sedimentary geothermal energy supply, the potential hazards of extraction, and the range of potential uses.  Our first target is geothermal energy for direct baseload electricial supply.  Geothermal brings the advantage of steady energy supply without generating CO2.  Our finding is that the heat in most all sedimentary basins is too low for the conventional flash/dry steam approaches used at most existing large geothermal power stations (e.g. The Geysers, CA).  The newer Rankin-cycle power generators, however, can generate electricity from water temperatures typcial of that extracted from sedimentary basins.  This is a new development and means geothermal heat can now be extracted from most sedimentary basins and converted directly to electricity.  From the start of our research we have seen our projections on geothermal energy from sedimentary basins change from "maybe for dollars to surely for pennies."  At the new state of pennies per killowatt hour, geothermal energy is practical and competitive with other energy sources.  It is still on the upper end of competitive costs though and is expanding at limited levels.  There are also risks.  Members of our group have confirmed potential for induced seismicity from overpressuring through high-volume water injection.  Care must be taked moving forward to assure that the rates of extraction and injection of water are properly balanced to assure the geothermal reservoir is never overly pressureized during operation.

Our work has make us understand that there are at least two potentially better uses for sedimentary geothermal energy.  First, geothermal fluids in sedimentary basins are at desirable temperatures for direct heating and cooling.  Over 25% of our electric usage is heating and cooling of spaces.  Geothermal waters can be used to replace these energy uses.  The use of shallow geothermal for this pupose at the domestic and small-scale commercial level has caught on in recent years.  Our research shows this can be upscaled to larger facilities using deeper wells from sedimentary basins.  Probably the most innovative and promising idea moving forward that incubated from our group is "Earth Battery."  Enormous amounts of solar energy can be generated during the warmest part of the day, but this is a short and generally low-consumption period.  The lack of ability to store solar power at megawatt scales has hampered its effectiveness and has created problems in the stability of the electric grid.  We propose that the excess heat generated from solar during the day could be used to heat water.  This water is then injected into the geothermal reservoir during the day.  The water in the geothermal reservoir is already near optimal temperatures and could be raised to optimal temeratures using this stored solar heat spike.  After the sun goes down, the geothermal plant ramps up to compensate for the lost solar power.  In this way, solar energy could be stabilized to a 24 hour baseload by coupling a solar with a geothermal system.  The low heat problem of geothermal and the erratic timing problem of solar are both solved together by merging them into one effective green energy system.  This can be implimented most anywhere in the U.S.  One of our task groups is currently confirming the logistics and economic feasibility of this coupled approach as a follow on NSF project incubated by SedHeat.
